constructs.name: chronotype
constructs.description: Genetic/stable tendency toward morning (lark) or evening (owl) preference, affecting circadian rhythm alignment with daily schedule

constructs.name: trait_anxiety
constructs.description: Stable personality trait reflecting baseline anxiety proneness and tendency to experience worry and apprehension

constructs.name: medical_sleep_conditions
constructs.description: Presence of sleep disorders such as sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome, or chronic insomnia that directly impair sleep

constructs.name: external_life_demands
constructs.description: Daily external obligations including work deadlines, caregiving responsibilities, and life events that place demands on time and mental resources

constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Overall quality of sleep including ease of falling asleep, sleep continuity, perceived depth, and feeling rested upon waking

constructs.name: presleep_arousal
constructs.description: Mental and physical activation state in the period before sleep, including racing thoughts, worry, rumination, and physical tension

constructs.name: daytime_stress
constructs.description: Perceived stress and psychological pressure experienced during waking hours from work, relationships, and life circumstances

constructs.name: caffeine_consumption
constructs.description: Amount and timing of caffeine intake from coffee, tea, energy drinks, and other sources throughout the day

constructs.name: alcohol_consumption
constructs.description: Amount of alcohol consumed, particularly in evening hours, which affects sleep architecture and continuity

constructs.name: physical_activity
constructs.description: Exercise and bodily movement during the day, affecting homeostatic sleep pressure and physiological readiness for sleep

constructs.name: evening_screen_exposure
constructs.description: Exposure to blue light from phones, computers, tablets and TVs in the hours before bed, affecting melatonin production and cognitive arousal

constructs.name: daytime_energy
constructs.description: Subjective energy level, alertness, and vitality during waking hours, reflecting sleep quality and recovery

constructs.name: mood_state
constructs.description: Daily emotional state including positive and negative affect, influenced by sleep, stress, and daily experiences

constructs.name: daytime_napping
constructs.description: Napping behavior during the day including frequency and duration, which reduces homeostatic sleep pressure

constructs.name: pain_discomfort
constructs.description: Physical pain, aches, or bodily discomfort experienced, which can interfere with falling asleep and maintaining sleep

edges.description: Higher trait anxiety amplifies perception of and emotional reactivity to daily stressors
Trait anxiety predisposes individuals to racing thoughts, worry, and cognitive hyperarousal at bedtime
Mismatch between innate chronotype and imposed schedule (social jetlag) affects daytime energy levels
Sleep disorders directly impair sleep quality through physiological mechanisms like airway obstruction or periodic limb movements
External obligations, deadlines, and responsibilities create psychological stress and pressure
High external demands reduce available time and energy for exercise and physical activity
Daily stress carries over into the pre-sleep period as rumination, worry, and physical tension
Stress leads to increased caffeine use to maintain alertness and cognitive performance under pressure
Stress drives evening alcohol consumption as a maladaptive coping mechanism to unwind and relax
Stress leads to distraction-seeking and avoidance behaviors through evening screen use
High daily stress leads to more negative emotional states including irritability and low mood
Stress increases muscle tension and pain perception through psychophysiological pathways
Higher energy enables and motivates physical activity; low energy reduces exercise engagement
Low energy drives compensatory caffeine consumption to combat fatigue and maintain function
Low energy increases the likelihood, frequency, and duration of daytime naps
Energy levels affect emotional state; fatigue and tiredness lead to worse mood and reduced positive affect
Negative mood leads to rumination, negative thought patterns, and difficulty quieting the mind before sleep
Physical pain directly interferes with sleep onset, maintenance, and depth through nociceptive arousal
Pain negatively affects emotional state, increasing negative affect and reducing well-being
Pain reduces ability, willingness, and motivation to engage in physical activity and exercise
Exercise improves mood through endorphin release, stress reduction, and sense of accomplishment
High mental and physical arousal before bed impairs the ability to fall asleep and reduces sleep quality
Caffeine blocks adenosine receptors, interfering with sleep onset, reducing deep sleep, and fragmenting sleep
Alcohol disrupts sleep architecture, suppresses REM sleep, causes rebound arousal, and fragments sleep continuity
Physical activity improves sleep through adenosine accumulation, thermoregulation, and anxiety reduction
Blue light from screens suppresses melatonin production and delays circadian phase, impairing sleep onset
Screen content and interaction increases cognitive and emotional arousal in the pre-sleep period
Daytime naps reduce homeostatic sleep pressure, potentially impairing nighttime sleep onset and reducing sleep depth
Negative mood impairs sleep through heightened physiological arousal and ruminative cognitive processes
Poor sleep leads to reduced energy, alertness, and vitality the following day
Sleep deprivation impairs emotional regulation, increases negative reactivity, and worsens mood the next day
Poor sleep increases stress reactivity, reduces coping capacity, and amplifies perceived stress
Poor sleep increases pain sensitivity and lowers pain thresholds through neuroinflammatory pathways
